name: Gongura Chicken (Andhra/Telugu)
steps: Blanch and grind gongura leaves to a coarse paste.
Heat oil, sauté sliced onion, garlic until golden.
Add chicken, turmeric, chili powder and sear.
Stir in gongura paste, add a splash of water and simmer until chicken is cooked.
Adjust salt and serve hot with steamed rice.
substitutions: Spinach can be used if gongura is unavailable (milder flavor).
Use ghee instead of mustard oil for milder taste.

name: Chettinad Paneer Curry (Tamil Nadu)
steps: Sauté chopped onions in oil until translucent with curry leaves.
Add tomatoes and chettinad masala; cook until oil separates.
Add paneer cubes and simmer for 5–7 minutes.
Garnish with coriander and serve with idli/dosa or rice.
substitutions: Tofu can replace paneer for a vegan version (use coconut yogurt).
Use less oil for a lighter curry.

name: Kerala Style Okra Poriyal (Kerala)
steps: Trim and slice okra lengthwise; keep dry to avoid sliminess.
Heat oil, temper mustard seeds and urad dal, add curry leaves.
Add okra and sauté on high heat until slightly charred and tender.
Mix in grated coconut and salt; cook 1–2 minutes and serve.
substitutions: Use sunflower oil instead of coconut oil.
Skip coconut for lower fat, add roasted peanuts for crunch.

name: Ragi Mudde with Sambar (Karnataka)
steps: Boil water with salt, reduce heat and add ragi flour gradually, stirring to form a smooth dough.
Knead well and shape into balls (mudde).
Serve hot with sambar and vegetable curry.
substitutions: Use millet flour mix if ragi unavailable.
Pair with rasam for lighter option.

name: Light Misal Pav (Maharashtra)
steps: Sauté onions and tomatoes, add misal masala and cooked matki; simmer.
Top with chopped onions, farsan (optional) and lemon.
Serve with small whole-wheat pav or brown bread.
substitutions: Use sprouted moong instead of matki for milder taste.
Serve with phulkas for healthier carb choice.

name: Khandvi (Healthy Oven/Skillet) (Gujarat)
steps: Whisk besan and yogurt with water to a smooth batter; add turmeric and salt.
Cook batter on low heat, stirring, until it thickens.
Spread thinly on a tray, cool slightly and roll into khandvi pieces.
Temper mustard seeds and pour over, garnish with coconut and coriander.
substitutions: Use plant-based yogurt for vegan version.
Bake thin layers to reduce oil usage.

name: Tandoori Chicken (Light) (Punjab)
steps: Marinate chicken in yogurt, tandoori masala, and ginger-garlic paste for at least 1 hour.
Bake or grill at high heat until charred and cooked through.
Serve with lemon wedges and salad.
substitutions: Use paneer for vegetarian skewers.
Air-fry for reduced oil.

name: Rajasthani Kadhi (Light) (Rajasthan)
steps: Whisk yogurt and besan to a smooth mixture; add turmeric and salt.
Cook the mixture gently until it thickens into kadhi consistency.
Temporarily skip deep-fried pakodas for a lighter version or bake small pakodas.
Temper with mustard oil, cumin and hing; garnish with coriander.
substitutions: Bake pakodas using minimal oil.
Use low-fat yogurt to reduce calories.

name: Cholar Dal with Coconut (Bengal)
steps: Cook chana dal until soft but holding shape.
Temper panch phoron in oil, add ginger and green chili.
Add cooked dal and grated coconut; simmer for 5 minutes.
Serve with steamed rice or luchi.
substitutions: Use split moong for softer texture.
Use less oil for lighter version.

name: Fish Paturi (Mustard-Banana Leaf) (Odisha)
steps: Marinate fish with mustard paste, green chili paste, turmeric and salt.
Wrap fillets in banana leaf and secure with toothpicks.
Steam or bake until fish is cooked and aromatic.
Serve hot with rice.
substitutions: Use light mustard paste (diluted) for milder flavor.
Aluminum foil if banana leaf unavailable.

name: Khar with Seasonal Vegetables (Assam)

ingredients.name: khar (alkaline extract) or baking soda solution

steps: Cook chopped vegetables until nearly tender.
Add khar solution and simmer briefly — do not overcook.
Finish with mustard oil and green chili; serve with rice.
substitutions: Use baking soda in water as a mild substitute (small amount).
Adjust vegetables based on seasonality.

name: Goan Prawn Curry (Light Coconut) (Goa)
steps: Sauté onions and add prawns; cook until pink.
Add goan masala and tamarind, pour coconut milk and simmer briefly.
Do not overcook prawns; serve with brown rice or ragi bhakri.
substitutions: Use fish fillet if prawns unavailable.
Use diluted coconut milk for lighter curry.

name: Rajma with Kashmiri Spices (Kashmir)
steps: Soak and cook rajma until tender.
Sauté onion and ginger, add spices and cooked rajma.
Simmer to thicken and serve with steamed rice or naan.
substitutions: Use chickpeas for chole-style variation.
Reduce oil for lighter version.

name: Chana Madra (Light Yogurt Chickpea Stew) (Himachal Pradesh)
steps: Cook chickpeas until tender.
Lightly temper whole spices, add chickpeas and whisked yogurt, simmer gently.
Finish with a small amount of ghee and serve with rice or roti.
substitutions: Use low-fat yogurt to reduce calories.
Add vegetables like pumpkin for variation.

name: Vegetable Xacuti (Light) (Konkani/Goa-Mangalorean influence)
steps: Cook vegetables until almost tender.
Add ground roasted coconut-poppy seed paste and xacuti masala; simmer until vegetables are done.
Serve with red rice or steamed rice.
substitutions: Use sunflower oil instead of coconut oil.
Skip potatoes to reduce carbs.

name: Baghara Baingan (Hyderabadi Brinjal Curry) (Telangana/Hyderabad)
steps: Roast or char eggplants and peel roughly.
Sauté onions and ginger-garlic paste, add peanut paste and tamarind.
Add eggplant, simmer and mash slightly; cook until flavors blend.
Serve with steamed rice or roti.
substitutions: Use roasted sesame paste for nuttier flavor.
Use less oil for lighter version.

name: Jeerakai Puliyam (Cumin-Tamarind Rice) (Mangalore/Coastal Karnataka)
steps: Temper cumin and mustard in oil, add green chili and tamarind; cook briefly.
Toss in cooked rice gently until evenly coated.
Serve with papad or pickle.
substitutions: Use brown rice for higher fiber.
Add roasted peanuts for crunch and protein.

name: Bhutte Ka Kees Inspired (Uttarakhand-style Corn) (Uttarakhand/Hill)
steps: Sauté mustard seeds and green chili, add grated corn and a splash of milk.
Cook until corn is tender and slightly creamy.
Finish with a dollop of ghee and serve hot.
substitutions: Use low-fat milk for lighter dish.
Add vegetables like peas for variety.

name: Ukthong Style Vegetable Stew (Manipur-inspired) (North East)
steps: Sauté ginger lightly, add vegetables and bamboo shoots if using.
Add water and simmer until vegetables are tender.
Add tofu towards the end and heat through; serve with rice.
substitutions: Use mushrooms instead of tofu for umami flavor.
Add a squeeze of lime for brightness.

name: Bamboo Shoot Fish Curry (Tripura-style) (North East)
steps: Temper panch phoron in oil, add bamboo shoots and fish.
Add a little water and simmer until fish is cooked through.
Adjust salt and serve with rice.
substitutions: Use light fish varieties like pomfret or surmai.
Replace mustard oil with neutral oil if preferred.

name: Kinema Stir-Fry (Sikkim-inspired Fermented Soy) (Sikkim)
steps: Sauté onion and green chili, add kinema and toss with soy sauce.
Cook for a few minutes until fragrant; serve with steamed rice.
substitutions: Use tempeh or firm tofu if kinema unavailable.
Add vegetables like capsicum for crunch.

name: Sattu Litti (Baked/Lighter) (Bihar/Maithili)
steps: Prepare dough with wheat flour and shape balls filled with spiced sattu mixture.
Bake or air-fry until golden instead of deep frying.
Serve with chokha (roasted brinjal/tomato mash) or curd.
substitutions: Use millet flour for gluten-free option.
Add roasted peanuts to sattu for extra protein.

name: Vegetable Seekh (Bihar-style Lighter Kebabs)
steps: Mix vegetables with besan and spices, shape onto skewers.
Bake or grill until set and lightly charred.
Serve with mint chutney.
substitutions: Use soya granules for higher protein.
Air-fry for minimal oil usage.

name: Sindhi Tindora (Dondakaya) Stir (Sindh/Western India influence)
steps: Sauté mustard seeds and onions, add sliced tindora and turmeric.
Cook on medium-high heat until tender and slightly charred.
Serve with roti or rice.
substitutions: Use snake gourd or zucchini if tindora unavailable.
Add grated coconut for southern twist.

name: Marwari Matar Kulcha (Baked) (Marwar/Rajasthan)
steps: Prepare dough and shallow-roll kulchas stuffed with spiced peas mixture.
Bake or tava-grill with minimal oil until golden.
Serve with curd or chutney.
substitutions: Use millet flour for gluten-free alternative.
Air-fry for lower oil content.

name: Light Muri Chaat with Peanuts (Bengal Street-style) (West Bengal)
steps: Mix muri, peanuts, chopped onion and green chili.
Season with salt and lemon; toss and serve immediately.
substitutions: Use roasted chana instead of peanuts for lower fat.
Add diced cucumber for freshness.

name: Spiced Crab Curry (Andaman-style, light coconut) (Andaman & Nicobar)
steps: Sauté ginger and garlic, add crab and spices.
Pour coconut milk and simmer until crab is cooked.
Serve with steamed rice.
substitutions: Use fish pieces for a milder curry.
Use less coconut milk for lighter dish.

name: Vegetable Thukpa (Light) (Ladakh/Himachal influence)
steps: Cook vegetables in broth until tender.
Add noodles and seasoning; cook until noodles are done.
Serve hot with chopped scallions.
substitutions: Use rice noodles for gluten-free option.
Add tofu for extra protein.

name: Smoked Tofu with Axone-flavored Broth (Nagaland-inspired) (North East)

ingredients.name: axone or fermented soybean paste (small amount)

steps: Sauté onion and green chili, add axone paste sparingly for umami.
Add smoked tofu and simmer briefly; serve with rice.
substitutions: Use tempeh as an alternative.
Skip axone if unavailable and add soy sauce for umami.

name: Bai (Steamed Mixed Vegetable with Bamboo Shoot) (Mizoram)
steps: Steam vegetables with bamboo shoots and ginger until tender.
Season lightly and serve with rice.
substitutions: Use cabbage and potato if seasonal vegetables unavailable.
Add a teaspoon of soybean paste for umami.

name: Yim (Tangy Vegetable Stew) (Nagaland/Naga-style)
steps: Sauté vegetables briefly, add water and simmer until soft.
Season with achar masala and (optional) fermented paste for depth.
Serve with rice.
substitutions: Skip fermented paste for vegetarian/vegan.
Use local pickling spice blend for achar masala.

name: Pesarattu Dosa (Green Gram Crepes) (Andhra Pradesh)
steps: Grind soaked moong with ginger and green chili to a smooth batter; add salt.
Spread thin on a hot tava with minimal oil and cook until crisp.
Serve with upma or chutney.
substitutions: Add rice a little for softer dosa.
Serve with vegetable upma for a balanced meal.

name: Mixed Vegetable Poriyal (Tamil Nadu)
steps: Temper mustard and urad dal, add vegetables and cook until tender.
Stir in grated coconut and serve with rice or rotis.
substitutions: Use less coconut for lower fat.
Add roasted peanuts for protein.
